title: Chipotle to close its Asian-themed ShopHouse restaurants
title_page: Chipotle to close its Asian-themed ShopHouse restaurants  | Daily Mail Online
text:
Chipotle has announced plans to close all 15 of its ShopHouse restaurants next week, ending its attempt to expand into fast casual Asian cuisine.
Late last year the company said it would be pulling the plug on ShopHouse restaurants, which are located in the Washington DC, Maryland, Los Angeles, and Chicago areas.
This week Chipotle said that all the restaurants would be serving their final meals next Friday.
Asian fusion restaurant ShopHouse will be closing all of its outlets on March 17
Once speculated as a billion-dollar brand, Asian fusion chain ShopHouse first opened in 2011, serving customizable rice, noodle, and salad bowls with curry, tamarind, peanut, and chili sauces and various toppings.
Last summer the chain also inexplicably started serving burritos.
The company has not revealed the exact reasons for axing the chain, but with only 15 stores across the country, ShopHouse never reached a critical mass as a brand, and its growth may have plateaued earlier than expected.
The company is also struggling to recover from a series of food safety outbreaks that have seen profits slashed.
One fan has set up a 'Save ShopHouse' Twitter account, protesting against the closure
Dozens of ShopHouse fans reacted with horror after the news was announced.
Marissa Marie tweeted: 'Nooooooooo! Please don't go! What will we eat?!'
While another Twitter user said: 'I'm soooo sad ShopHose is closing for good on March 17th!!!!! Omggg no. This is heart breaking it's so good.'
And Jaclyn Silva‏ said simply: 'I refuse to accept this.'
One fan has even set up a 'Save ShopHouse' Twitter account, protesting against plans to shut the chain.
The chain has been in a downward spiral since October 2015 when news broke about a highly publicized E. coli outbreak
Last month it was announced that Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc's quarterly profits had fallen by 76.5 per cent as the company struggles to recover from a prolonged food safety crisis in the fall of 2015.
The company is blaming minimum wage increases, higher spending on advertising, promotions and a spike in costs for avocados, the main ingredient in guacamole.
The company's net income fell to $15.98million, or 55 cents per share, in the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, from $67.87million, or $2.17 per share, a year earlier.
Despite the fall in profits, Chipotle's sales rose for the first time in five quarters.
Chipotle's share prices have fallen dramatically over the past 18 months as the company struggles to recovered from a series of food safety outbreaks
The burrito chain is going it all it can to bring back diners after a series of food safety lapses.
The company said sales at established restaurants jumped 26 percent in January, putting it on track for its first quarterly increase in six quarters.
Chipotle's sales slumped in November 2015 when the chain was linked to a multi-state E. coli outbreak. A month later, at least 80 Boston College students were sickened by norovirus traced to a Chipotle restaurant.
Since then, the company has given away free and discounted food and spent heavily on advertising and promotions in a bid to bring back diners. It also abandoned its dual CEO structure and named Steve Ells the sole chief executive.
Following the closure of ShopHouse, Chipotle will focus on its two other growth concepts, the Pizzeria Locale pizza chain, and Tasty Made, its new burger joint that opened its first branch in October.
